1

Best for Breakage

K18 Biomimetic Hairscience Damage Shield pH Protective Shampoo

Pros
  • Adds volume by removing excess oils
Cons
  • Some hair types might need more moisture

You may not realize it, but the simple act of shampooing can aggravate weak, damaged hair. This shampoo was made with fragile strands in mind, making it gentle and pH-balanced. It's also packed with peptides to strengthen stressed-out hair.

Hair type: Fragile

Size: 8.5 fl. oz.

Sulfate-free: Yes

Amazon rating: 4.5/5 stars

An ELLE editor says: “When I started using this shampoo, I noticed an immediate difference in my hair. I’m extremely prone to frizz and flyaways, but this works like a sealant for hair, making it all but impervious to heat and humidity.” —Katie Berohn, ELLE beauty editor

2

Best for Chemically Treated Hair

Olaplex No.4 Bond Maintenance Shampoo

Pros
  • Strengthens damaged hair
Cons
  • Should be alternated with a detoxing shampoo

Post-bleach or coloring, hair can become weak and prone to breakage and frizz. This shampoo repairs and reverses the damage, leading to stronger and smoother hair.

Hair type: Damaged

Size: 8.5 fl. oz.

Sulfate-free: Yes

Amazon rating: 4.6/5 stars

An ELLE editor says: “I always find myself going back to Olaplex. I really do think that when I use it, my hair feels stronger and less prone to frizz. I also love how the whole Olaplex range smells.”—Katie Berohn

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

3

Best for Unruly Hair

Matrix Total Results Mega Sleek Shampoo

Pros
  • Makes frizzy hair feel soft and hydrated
Cons
  • May be too heavy for fine hair types

For hair that needs a reboot, this shampoo will get it in line. Fun packaging aside, it’s packed with shea butter that will help calm down frizz while giving your hair the moisture it desires.

Hair type: Frizzy, dry

Size: 10.1 fl. oz.

Sulfate-free: No

Amazon rating: 4.6/5 stars

An Amazon reviewer says: “Great product. I have very coarse hair that gets tangled when I wash it. This conditioner detangles and leaves my hair shinier than other conditioners.”

4

Best for Humid Environments

John Frieda Frizz Ease Beyond Smooth Frizz-Immunity Shampoo

Pros
  • Helps prevent and combat frizz
Cons
  • Can leave build-up in the hair

If you live anywhere humid, you know battling frizz is practically a lifestyle. This shampoo contains coconut oil, which not only smells delicious but also reduces frizz and protects your hair from humidity.

Hair type: Frizzy

Size: 8.45 fl. oz.

Sulfate-free: Yes

Amazon rating: 4.5/5 stars

An Amazon reviewer says: “I’ve noticed my hair feels better. I don't use conditioner on my hair as much. My hair has much less frizz and I live in a very humid climate. I’ve told several people how much I like this product.”

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

5

Best for All Hair Types

Eva NYC Mane Magic 10-in-1 Shampoo

Pros
  • Delivers ultra-hydrating properties to hair strands
Cons
  • Some reviewers wish the bottle was bigger

If you think your hair is beyond repair, it’s time to turn to this shampoo from Eva NYC. Formulated with argan oil and baobab seed, this shampoo reduces the appearance of breakage, thoroughly cleanses your strands, and returns moisture to over-processed hair.

Hair type: Frizzy, dry

Size: 8.8 fl. oz.

Sulfate-free: Yes

Eva NYC rating: 4.6/5 stars

An Eva NYC reviewer says: “Amazing shampoo that smells so good. Makes hair super soft, frizz free and shiny and manageable. Highly recommend this for frizzy hair.”

6

Fekkai Brilliant Gloss Shampoo

Cons

Fekkai’s Brilliant Gloss Shampoo is the antidote your hair needs if it’s desperate for a glossy, smooth look that only hydration can provide. This product contains olive oil and prickly pear oil, which nurtures, protects, and eliminates frizz.

Hair type: Frizzy

Size: 8.45 fl. oz.

Living Proof No Frizz Shampoo

Cons

Product buildup, sweat, and excess sebum are no match for this shampoo, which also has the ability to block frizz. Its secret weapon? Jojoba esters, which are derived from jojoba oil, and infuses each strand with plenty of hydration.

Hair type: Frizzy

Size: 8.5 fl. oz.

Sulfate-free: Yes

An Amazon reviewer says: “I have had a long battle with my very thick, long, mostly straight, sometimes wavy, always frizzy hair. When I let it air dry, it gets so frizzy that I’ll only wear it up in a clip or messy bun—not even a ponytail. I’ve spent all of high school, college, and grad school straightening it because I didn’t know how else to deal with it, but now that I’m married with a child, I just don’t have the time. I’ve tried tons of shampoos and conditioners and recently gave up on the idea that they could ever make a difference. On a whim, I decided to splurge and try this one, with the matching conditioner, and I actually noticed a big difference in my hair after just air drying! Not only is it less frizzy, but it is also somehow softer and less dry looking.”

Meet the Expert

Allison Chin is the director of product development at Eva NYC, an innovative hair care brand based in Brooklyn, NY. Chin and her colleagues have worked to ensure that all Eva NYC products are vegan, cruelty-free, and non-GMO.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

What should you look for in an anti-frizz shampoo?

As Chin mentioned, the best anti-frizz shampoos are sulfate-free formulas containing moisturizing ingredients, such as oil and glycerin (a compound derived from fatty acids). As for the oils that provide ample hydration, you’ll want to consider anti-frizz shampoos that contain argan oil, castor oil, and jojoba oil. “More importantly, caring agents that effectively smooth the entire surface of the hair fiber are essential for combating frizz, such as conditioning polymers and some lightweight silicones,” adds Chin.

Are there certain types of shampoos that those with frizzy hair should avoid?

“Shampoos that are overly drying or not conditioning enough should be avoided, as they will aggravate frizz,” Chin explains. You’ll likely know whether or not a shampoo is drying depending on whether its formula contains excessive sulfate. Sulfates, chemicals acting as cleansing agents, can often strip away the hair’s natural oil, leaving strands dehydrated and brittle.

Before joining the team, she was an editor at Food Network Magazine and HGTV Magazine and ran the beauty section at The Pioneer Woman. Carol received her bachelor’s degree in Journalism from New York University and was one of the first customers to visit Glossier’s flagship store in New York’s Soho neighborhood. Over the years, she’s tested countless makeup, hair, and skin care products, and written hundreds of articles covering the beauty space, from pieces about the trendiest launches to roundups of the best products on the market. As a Korean-American, she grew up in a sea of Korean makeup and skin care products and is a bona fide expert on the ever-expanding world of K-beauty, helping lead our coverage. Additionally, she’s also always on the hunt for the perfect lipstick and watches the same few comfort sitcoms (Frasier, Cheers, Seinfeld, New Girl, etc.) over and over again.
